fields.label_text: On 25th August 1858 the museum's photographer C. Thurston Thompson was granted £2, 2 shillings a day travelling expenses, and 15 shillings a day allowance, for photographing the Cartoons which at that date were still at Hamptom Court. Five sizes of photograph subseqnetly went on sale at the museum, of which this is the second largest. A review in <u>The Athenaeum</u> in January 1859 called them "all but as valuable as the originals... the Cartoons are now safe and sown over the world for ever. Great works of Art are now when once photographed, imperishable and must last while the world lasts." In 1865 when the Cartoons were lent to the museum a set of these photographs was annotated with notes on the condition of the Cartoons such as "a vile overpaint".

fields.materials_techniques: albumen print from a collodion negative
fields.label: On 25th August 1858 the museum's photographer C. Thurston Thompson was granted £2, 2 shillings a day travelling expenses, and 15 shillings a day allowance, for photographing the Cartoons which at that date were still at Hamptom Court. Five sizes of photograph subseqnetly went on sale at the museum, of which this is the second largest. A review in <u>The Athenaeum</u> in January 1859 called them "all but as valuable as the originals... the Cartoons are now safe and sown over the world for ever. Great works of Art are now when once photographed, imperishable and must last while the world lasts." In 1865 when the Cartoons were lent to the museum a set of these photographs was annotated with notes on the condition of the Cartoons such as "a vile overpaint". [1995]
fields.public_access_description:
The so-called Raphael Cartoons are seven full size designs for tapestries by the great Italian Renaissance artist Raphael (1483-1520). They illustrate passages from the Bible concerning the lives of Saint Peter and Saint Paul. None of them is smaller than ten feet high by thirteen feet wide. They belong to Her Majesty the Queen and have been on loan to this museum since 1865. 

On the 25th August 1858 the Victoria and Albert Museum's photographer Charles Thurston Thompson was granted £2.2 shillings a day travelling expenses, and 15 shillings a day allowance, for photographing the Raphael Cartoons which at that date were still at Hampton Court. Five sizes of photograph subsequently went on sale at the museum, of which this is the second largest. A review in 'The Athenaeum' in January 1859 called them "all but as valuable as the originals....the Cartoons are now safe and sown over the world for ever. Great works of Art are now when once photographed, imperishable and must last while the world lasts." In 1865 when the Cartoons were lent to the museum a set of these photographs was annotated with notes on the condition of the Cartoons such as "a vile overpaint".
fields.exhibition_history: From Marcantonio Raimondi to the Postcard: Prints of the Raphael Cartoons (Victoria & Albert Museum, Prints Gallery, Henry Cole Wing 17/09/1995-30/04/2004)
